stream_context.summary: Kaze restores Course 7 to working order, previews overworld progress, and wrestles with a Windows 11/toolchain transition (Blender 4.2, new texture editors). The stream surfaces practical N64 art constraints (CI4 palettes, transparency color, bilinear filtering), rejects AI-generated textures as production-ready, and sets up near-term goals: add Yoshi coins, free RAM for Luigi, and build the next overworld sections (beach, waves, Bowser’s oil tanker).
stream_context.significance_reason: Course 7 is brought back to full functionality; Kaze lays out a concrete Luigi-integration plan constrained by RAM; and he gives a detailed, production-relevant explanation of N64 texture transparency/bilinear filtering while rebuilding the texture pipeline after a Windows 11 update.

findings.summary: Course 7 is “fully functional again” after Kaze updated assets (including sounds) and validated the stage; remaining work is to place the five Yoshi coins.
findings.quote: Course 7 is now fully functional again. I just need to add the five Yoshi coins.

findings.summary: Kaze updated to Windows 11 to recover disk space and stabilize a broken Windows 10 install, but the transition forces pipeline changes (switching from Sony Vegas to DaVinci Resolve, updating Blender) and introduces instability (blue screens, slow Blender loads, missing TGA viewing/editing tools).

Kaze explains a key N64 art constraint: transparent pixels still carry color, and N64 bilinear filtering blends edges with that hidden color; incorrect hidden colors (e.g., Photoshop exporting transparent pixels as white) cause visible white outlines around transparent decals/textures in-game.
findings.quote: Transparent pixels have a color too. And the N64's bilinear filtering will blend your textures into the background's color.

findings.summary: Texture authoring workflow is constrained by CI4 palette limits; Kaze tests Krita (rejects it as not meeting needs) and returns to GIMP, noting recurring palette-index quirks (needing 15 colors to get a 16-color export because transparency handling is inconsistent).
findings.quote: You need to put 15 colors to get 16 colors.

findings.summary: Kaze argues against using AI-generated textures in RTYI for both quality control (seams, style mismatch, resolution/noise problems) and audience perception, stating that using AI would provoke backlash and harm the game’s reception.
findings.quote: With anything AI you have to keep in mind there is a huge debuff because people hate it and people are going to hate your game for using AI.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions a custom in-development Project64 build he uses; the standout improvement is functional audio, supporting his goal of hardware-accurate testing while still using emulator tooling.
findings.quote: I have a completely custom version of Project64 now… The most important one is that the audio actually works.

findings.summary: Luigi is now a near-term feature: Kaze likes a Luigi model made in RTYI’s style (matching Biobak’s Mario) and expects to import Luigi soon, but plans to first delete unused files to free enough RAM for Luigi to fit.
findings.quote: I'm probably importing the Luigi this week… I can start cleaning out some unused files… and it will open up enough memory for Luigi to fit into RAM.

findings.summary: Kaze runs a quick performance check on widescreen mode and reports only a small FPS drop (example: ~36 FPS down to ~33.5 FPS), suggesting widescreen is not a major performance risk for most scenes tested.

Overworld art direction continues to lean on layered detail to fake depth and higher apparent texture resolution (multiple textured quads, decals like mushroom clusters, and planned foreground elements to build 3D richness within N64 constraints).

Kaze outlines the next overworld production targets: finish the current section (including the tree), then build a small beach segment, then “Bowser’s oil tanker,” and later add waves, forest work, and an overworld background; he frames this as finishing ‘part 10’ with parts 11–13 remaining afterward.
findings.quote: We are ready to move towards the next part of the overworld… then we're gonna have to make Bowser's oil tanker… and we still need to make waves… the forest… [and] a background for the overworld.

findings.summary: Kaze discusses a potential paid commission: someone may pay ~$5000 for a fast ‘Groot’ themed major ROM hack; he describes an approach of speed-modeling ~15 environments, preparing ~100 textures, and building a 120-star hack in about a month, similar in spirit to how quickly he made ‘SM64 Madness.’
findings.quote: If the guy pays $5000 for it… we will speedrun making a Groot major hack… within like a month. With 120 stars.

biobak.summary: Biobak is referenced as the creator of RTYI’s Mario model style that a new Luigi model is matching; Kaze explicitly wants Biobak to see the Luigi model and implies stylistic continuity is important.
Kaze mentions Biobak has been teasing an upcoming area/level concept (‘Divine Dino Domain’ / Dino Domain), implying a planned future focus area that the team has been anticipating.

zeina.summary: Zeina supplies a mushroom-cluster decal/texture asset that Kaze processes into N64-compatible constraints (palette/indexing, transparency color). Kaze requests a version without grass and with transparency prepared correctly for filtering.
Kaze reacts to Zeina’s shadow/colour choices on the mushroom cluster (noting blue shadows may be odd) but continues testing it in-game, indicating iterative art-direction feedback between them.

findings.summary: Pixelpalabra made an RTYI Luigi model in the same style as the project’s Mario model; Kaze strongly approves and plans to import it soon, pending RAM/file cleanup.
findings.quote: He does really look like the Luigi version of Mario… I'm probably importing the Luigi this week.

findings.summary: Lilaa advocates for using a Blender fork due to perceived stability/hotkey issues, while Kaze resists branching away from mainline Blender to avoid losing upstream features and ecosystem support.
Lilaa (and chat) push Kaze to try AI texture generation tools; Kaze runs a live experiment and uses the results to justify not adopting AI textures for RTYI.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This all runs on real hardware. That's the whole point.
memorable_quotes.context: Stated while discussing testing and tooling (including emulator changes), reinforcing the project’s guiding constraint: authenticity to N64 hardware limits.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Transparent pixels have a color too. And the N64's bilinear filtering will blend your textures into the background's color.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear, documentary-friendly explanation of why RTYI’s art pipeline has to be unusually strict compared to modern engines, and why seemingly minor tool quirks create visible artifacts.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: With anything AI you have to keep in mind there is a huge debuff because people hate it and people are going to hate your game for using AI.
memorable_quotes.context: Connects a production decision (no AI textures) to audience trust and the ethics/perception of authenticity—highly relevant to ‘respectful’ reinterpretation of a classic.

key_stories.title: Restoring Course 7 after updates and regressions
key_stories.summary: Kaze validates that Course 7 is functional again after updating assets and ensuring compatibility. The remaining work is scoped clearly: add five Yoshi coins and continue forward rather than reworking the course again.
key_stories.challenge: Course content needed re-validation after updates (sounds/assets/compatibility) to ensure it still runs correctly, including on real hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze boots the level, checks performance/behavior, and confirms it has returned to a working state; he identifies the remaining collectible placement task.
key_stories.outcome: Course 7 is declared functional with a small, concrete task left (five Yoshi coins).
key_stories.key_quote: Course 7 is now fully functional again. I just need to add the five Yoshi coins.

key_stories.title: Rebuilding the texture pipeline under N64 constraints after the Windows 11 switch
key_stories.summary: A Windows 11 upgrade breaks or changes parts of Kaze’s workflow (tool availability, stability, hotkeys), forcing him to test Krita and then return to GIMP for palette indexing and transparency control. The segment becomes a practical case study in why N64-era rendering constraints still dominate day-to-day decisions in RTYI.
key_stories.challenge: Creating decal-style textures (mushroom clusters) that look clean in-game requires correct palette size and correct ‘hidden’ transparent pixel colors to avoid filtering halos, but Kaze’s previous tools are no longer available or reliable.
key_stories.process: He tests AI generation (rejects results), then tests Krita (rejects functionality), then uses GIMP to control alpha/background colors and CI4 palette exports while checking for known bugs and verifying palette byte counts.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze gets a usable mushroom cluster in-game and clarifies the exact technical rulebook for future transparent textures, while recognizing ongoing tool friction.
key_stories.key_quote: Photoshop… always exports the transparent pixels as being fully white… you’re going to get a model in-game with a white outline.

key_stories.title: Planning Luigi as a memory-budget feature
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcases a Luigi model that matches RTYI’s character style and plans to add Luigi soon. The blocker is not artistry but N64 RAM budget and project hygiene: he expects to delete unused files to make Luigi fit.
key_stories.challenge: Adding a new playable character/model risks exceeding memory limits on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze evaluates the model quality, sets a short timeline for importing, and proposes a cleanup pass to remove unused assets/files to reclaim memory.
key_stories.outcome: Luigi is positioned as an imminent addition contingent on cleanup and RAM headroom.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm gonna start deleting stuff to make space for Luigi.

questions: What specifically caused Course 7 to stop being ‘fully functional’ earlier—engine changes, asset changes, scripting, performance regressions, or hardware-only bugs?

open_questions.topic: Luigi integration plan and technical requirements
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to import Pixelpalabra’s Luigi soon, but expects to first delete unused files to free RAM so Luigi ‘fits into RAM.’
questions: What exactly must be in RAM simultaneously for RTYI (Mario/Luigi model, animations, level geo, textures, audio banks), and what is the current headroom?

open_questions.topic: Texture/alpha pipeline rules for RTYI and the team’s asset handoff process
open_questions.context: Kaze gives a detailed explanation of transparent pixel colors and filtering, and he needs Zeina’s decals prepared to avoid halos and to meet CI4 palette limits.
questions: What is the ‘official’ RTYI texture spec for contributors (palette format CI4/CI8, target resolutions like 32x32, requirements for hidden transparent pixel color, filtering assumptions)?
How do Kaze and Zeina coordinate on decals—does Zeina deliver layered source files, and does Kaze do final indexing/export, or should artists deliver already-indexed assets?
What are the most common artifact types you fight on N64 (white/colored outlines, shimmering, banding, seams), and which ones are acceptable vs. must-fix?

open_questions.topic: Custom Project64 build and hardware-accuracy philosophy
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a custom in-development Project64 where audio ‘actually works’ and reiterates the goal of running on real hardware.
questions: Who is building the custom Project64 fork, and what exact problems is it solving for RTYI development (audio sync, timing, RSP/RDP accuracy, debugging hooks)?

What were the most surprising differences you’ve encountered between emulator behavior and real N64 for RTYI?
